head.title: Comprehensive Decision Framework Combining Price Prediction and Production-Planning Models for Strategic Operation of a Petrochemical Industry | Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research

meta.content: Comprehensive Decision Framework Combining Price Prediction and Production-Planning Models for Strategic Operation of a Petrochemical Industry

This paper presents a new decision-making framework for resource and production planning in the petrochemical industry under price uncertainty conditions. The framework consists of three main decision models: price prediction, paper trading, and production planning. Three different prediction models, system dynamics, multiple linear regression, and artificial neural network, were examined and compared for the precise forecasting of the price of the final products as well as naphtha as a raw material. We then developed a new optimization model using a mixed integer linear programming technique to establish the optimal operational strategies with a given inventory capacity. In the framework, the maximum profitability is ensured by solving a series of decision-making problems on the petrochemical plant, including timing and quantity of naphtha purchase and final product sales, inventory management, financial risk management with paper trading, and operation strategy of the involved processes. To illustrate the capability of the proposed model, the resource and production planning problem of a real petrochemical plant that produces six different major products, ethylene, propylene, butadiene, benzene, toluene, and xylene, was examined. As a result, the optimal production planning using the proposed model enabled the improvement of the total sales by 5.50% and the operating profit by 13.8% in comparison with the BAU case.

div.p: This paper presents a new decision-making framework for resource and production planning in the petrochemical industry under price uncertainty conditions. The framework consists of three main decision models: price prediction, paper trading, and production planning. Three different prediction models, system dynamics, multiple linear regression, and artificial neural network, were examined and compared for the precise forecasting of the price of the final products as well as naphtha as a raw material. We then developed a new optimization model using a mixed integer linear programming technique to establish the optimal operational strategies with a given inventory capacity. In the framework, the maximum profitability is ensured by solving a series of decision-making problems on the petrochemical plant, including timing and quantity of naphtha purchase and final product sales, inventory management, financial risk management with paper trading, and operation strategy of the involved processes. To illustrate the capability of the proposed model, the resource and production planning problem of a real petrochemical plant that produces six different major products, ethylene, propylene, butadiene, benzene, toluene, and xylene, was examined. As a result, the optimal production planning using the proposed model enabled the improvement of the total sales by 5.50% and the operating profit by 13.8% in comparison with the BAU case.

div.div:
In the petrochemical industry, intelligent decision making involving resource trade, production planning, resource inventory, and risk management is of paramount importance to ensure the profitability, logistic reliability, and financial safety at the plant and enterprise levels.
(1)
Furthermore, the prices of raw materials and products have shown astonishing variations in the global petrochemical market, which has one of the worldâs longest and most complex supply chains. Thus, decision making in a petrochemical plant should cope with both external challenges and internal issues (e.g., energy efficiency and cost reduction) to sustain its competitiveness.

Production planning, as one of the critical strategies to maintain profit margins, covers a wide range of decision problems. These include resource management (including timing and quantities of purchases), product quality management (through efficient operation of the involved processes), and inventory management (according to market conditions). In the petrochemical industry, the importance of appropriate production planning is particularly marked, as its worldwide supply chain is facing a stiff competition, and its markets require a demand-driven model rather than the conventional supply-driven one. A number of studies have attempted to solve the production-planning problems in this industry. In particular, recent reports focus on a better understanding of the nonlinear aspects in petrochemical processes, such as complex catalytic reactions, integrating the supply chain with the petrochemical planning considering various uncertainties (e.g., growing demand for petrochemical products, increasing raw materials costs, and internal or external environment constraints). For instance, a new mathematical optimization model was developed to ensure the maximum business profit in the Norwegian petrochemical industry.
(2)
The mixed integer linear programming (MILP) technique was used for developing an optimization model that identifies synergic benefits with mergers and acquisitions in the Korean petrochemical industry.
(3)
Other studies have focused on solving specific problems in the petrochemical industry, including efficient planning and scheduling of the petrochemical production with multiple product portfolios, optimal supply chain management, and capacity expansion.
(4â6)

To ensure a sustainable operation and management in a petrochemical plant, diverse objectives must have been addressed within the production-planning problems. Such objectives are formulated in the form of an objective function in an optimization model. This not only minimizes the operation costs but also minimizes the raw material requirement for high security, minimizes the harmful environmental impacts, and maximizes the annual profit within a specific regional environment.
(7â10)
Additionally, the Karimi group developed an agent-based decision support system (DSSs) framework for a supply chain and a petroleum-refinery integrated supply chain modeler and simulator (PRISMS) for a decision-supporting tool for crude oil procurement.
(11,12)
These systems facilitate integrated decisions in terms of the refinery business. However, their studies only provide insight into responding to changes in domestic policies and unexpected events in the international environment. GÃ¶the-Lundgren, Lundgren, and Persson solved the scheduling problem based on the mixed-integer programming (MIP) model, including utilization of the production process.
(13)
They formulated an optimization model for production scheduling that can support the decisions of procurement planners at the strategic, tactical, and operational planning levels. However, the developed model is only designed to integrate planning with production scheduling and does not focus on support for procurement or purchase plan decisions. Zhang, Wen, and Xu introduced the mixed integer nonlinear programming (MINLP) technique for optimization of crude oil blending and purchase planning with uncertainty.
(14)
This is a significant contribution to decision support that considers the short-term process operation and long-term purchase planning simultaneously.

Thus, to maintain the profitability in the aforementioned complex environments with a large uncertainty, the enterprises in the petrochemical industry need to establish intelligent decision making for less-risky, flexible, and adaptive production planning. Whereas the conventional decision-making tools and practices have provided converged solutions for petrochemical plant planning and scheduling problems, a new decision-making framework capable of addressing all the external challenges and internal issues should be proposed. Accordingly, the goal of this study is to develop a novel decision model to support efficient production planning by embedding product price prediction into an optimization-based planning framework to reduce the aforementioned uncertainty, thereby ensuring sustained profit margins.

The proposed framework consists of a financial risk model through precise price prediction for determining timing, quantity, and price of raw material purchases and a plant planning and scheduling risk model to establish the operation strategy of the involved processes to correspond to variable production goals according to the price variation of the final products. The proposed framework is capable of maximizing total revenue by adopting a price prediction model that reduces the business risks for purchase or sales prices in the market. This paper is organized as follows. In
Section 2
, the optimization problem is described.
Section 3
introduces a mathematical model for production planning with the financial risk management technique and for determining the timing of sales of the final products.
Section 4
discusses the results of various case studies regarding profit improvement. The final section presents the concluding remarks.

A petrochemical plant handles various feedstocks such as representative naphtha, natural gas, and condensate to produce a wide range of primary petrochemicals, including ethylene, propylene, butadiene, benzene, toluene, and xylene. These various petrochemical products are important building blocks in a series of very complex and large-scale chemical networks; hence, the petrochemical industry is highly capital intensive.
(15)
These primary petrochemicals have an enormous economic significance according to the types of raw materials used. For example, most petrochemical industries in Middle Eastern countries have started to use their own resources to export intermediate or final products with increasing benefits for their economies.
(16,17)
The petrochemical sector is predicted to be worth approximately USD 600 billion globally and is a very competitive market.
(18)
Furthermore, the profit margin is very sensitive to the markets of petrochemical products. To maximize the operating profit, a petrochemical company should sell products at their most favorable periods, when high selling prices are available (or predicted). Thereby, the production plan of a petrochemical plant should be established with precise price information on its major products. In this sense, this study proposes an optimal production-planning model, which is capable not only of establishing an optimal operation policy but also of managing the financial risk derived from purchasing raw materials and selling the final products. Accordingly, the decision variables determined by the proposed model are associated with decision-making problems on the petrochemical value chain such as the amount and timing of purchase of raw materials, the inventory levels, and the amount of sales of the final products.
Figure
1

div.div:
In other aspects, the petrochemical companies need to consider a risk management system to ensure sustained profit margins against the uncertainty of raw material prices. For example, most Korean petrochemical companies import over 90% of their raw materials from the Middle East, and the delivery to destination takes approximately two months. Therefore, they could mitigate a financial risk using one (or multiple) paper trades. As mentioned previously, the petrochemical companies are sensitive to market conditions, which change rapidly. The operating profit of a petrochemical company depends largely on the expenses for purchasing raw materials and the revenue from the sales of the final products. Therefore, it is difficult for most petrochemical companies to establish a precise production plan owing to the changeable prices of raw materials and final products. To handle the financial risk caused by the variation of raw materials and petrochemical prices and to establish sustainable operation strategies, a number of petrochemical companies have adopted a hedge trade system.
(19)
Hedge indicates that the investment position of the buyer is meant to offset potential gains or losses that might be incurred by forward-looking investment. For instance, most petrochemical companies have been purchasing naphtha (one of their main raw materials) using a hedge trade.
(20)

To reflect the aforementioned hedge trade of the petrochemical industry into the proposed framework, this study considers the short-term planning for naphtha purchase, which covers wide-range decision problems such as the number, timing, and quantity of purchases, inventory level management, and operability of the main processes (e.g., production level of a naphtha-cracking unit). This means that a naphtha purchase plan is established by the optimization model to minimize the purchase cost by identifying the optimal timing and quantity of spot trading. The average market prices of naphtha are predicted using a reliable forecasting model proposed in this study. The assumptions in the establishment of the naphtha purchase plan through hedge trading for financial risk management are as follows:
All of the purchases and sales take place once a month.
The period of transportation of naphtha from origin to destination is two months.
Paper trading is realized twice during two months.
Other financial risk factors are ignored.
The time interval in the planning is a month.

Therefore, the overall optimization problem consists of determining the following: (1) the timing and quantity of naphtha purchase, (2) the timing and quantity of sales of final products, and (3) the inventory management strategy (tank levels of raw materials and products) to ensure the maximum profit margin from plant operation over a planning period. To solve the aforementioned problems simultaneously, this study integrates different decision models into a single framework as shown in
Figure
2
. The optimal production planning (e.g., naphtha-cracking yield) is established based on the predicted prices of naphtha and the final products. Further, the optimal timing and quantity of naphtha purchasing and products sales are determined by considering the levels of the storage tanks and the prices for ensuring the maximum profit margin. For instance, the naphtha price prediction using paper trading makes the decision of the maximum naphtha purchase at a lower price to store at a higher level of inventory. Also, the price prediction with the market conditions and storage level of products was considered to set the plant operation. The optimization model determines the decision variables for planning of a petrochemical plant, such as the amount of raw materials required, inventory levels of raw materials and products, amount of sales of the final product, and process unit operability. The model is iterated with initial values (i.e., raw materials and final product inventory levels) until the optimal solutions within upper and lower boundaries are found. Consequently, the operation policy is adapted to operate a naphtha-cracking reactor and subsequent processing for the maximum profit.

div.div: The proposed comprehensive decision framework consists mainly of two different models: price prediction model for determining precise purchase timing and price, and paper trading for establishing the production planning of the petrochemical plant.

Price prediction is very important for the determination of the optimal timing of raw material purchasing and product selling. The prediction model of the prices of naphtha and petrochemical products is based on the time series (monthly variations). The prediction model usually includes the following different tasks:
Step 1: Collect historical data and statistics of price variation behavior.
Step 2: Select the major factors with effects on the price variation.
Step 3: Normalize the predicted prices
Step 4: Analyze quantitatively and qualitatively the predicted price variations compared with the actual price variation.
Step 5: Identify the correlations between factors and make a casual loop.

Although numerous methods are widely used for price prediction, this study compares three different prediction models for a highly accurate prediction of the prices of naphtha and petrochemical products.
(21)

To predict the market prices of the six major products from a petrochemical plant (ethylene, propylene, butadiene, benzene, toluene, and xylene), this study considered 35 descriptors influencing the petrochemical products. These include historical prices, quantities of demand and supply, price profiles of other reference chemicals (e.g., crude oil), and financial statistics (e.g., margin and cash flow). All the selected factors, which are historical monthly data from May 2009 to December 2010, are used for training the prediction models (MLR, ANN, and SD) to predict future prices from January 2011 to December 2011. Note that this study deals with a short-term prediction for three months in advance involving possible internal and external problems that might occur, including emergency shutdown and unexpected political incidents. However, a majority of the forecasting models published are based on a quantitative approach, which is difficult to apply to real situations. The prices predicted with the SD model were used as raw data for the operation strategy model of the petrochemical plant. Another reason for selecting the SD model in this study is its capability for quantitative and qualitative analysis. Whereas the MLR and ANN models are very powerful to predict the output values (here, future prices), they are limited in providing causality through a quantitative analysis (here, correlation and dynamics between descriptors and to the output). More detailed information about the SD model for the prediction of petrochemical product prices can be found in the Lyu et al. study, which analyzed naphtha demand and supply in a real market using the SD model.
(24,25)

In this study, we predicted the prices of major products such as ethylene, propylene, butadiene, benzene, toluene, and xylene using the developed SD model considering time-series data. For instance,
Figure
3
a and b present the causal loop and the output (ethylene price) and a comparison of the actual and simulation result of the ethylene price using the SD model and other models (MLR, ANN), respectively. Again, this causal loop is helpful to understand the correlation and dynamics between descriptors, such as the correlation between the crude oil price and naphtha margin or between other petrochemical prices and naphtha. Similar to the product price prediction problem, the price of naphtha as a raw material in a petrochemical plant was predicted using the SD model. Notably, the point of naphtha purchase is determined by the fluctuation of the naphtha price.

In this study, the production-planning model in the petrochemical industry is executed to maximize the operating profit using paper trading with the predicted prices of a raw material (naphtha) and the final products. The planning problems are solved using the MILP solver of gPROMS. All the decision variables in the optimization model are determined to ensure the highest operating profit by manipulating a production policy (yield of the naphtha-cracking process). For instance, if the price of ethylene as a main product is expected to increase in the next month, the decision maker operates the plant to maintain the maximum level of the ethylene storage tank by increasing the ethylene yield and/or decreasing the sales this month. Herein, it was assumed that the capacity of the petrochemical plant is 3.6 million ton of naphtha per year. Accordingly, the capacity of the naphtha-cracking process is 0.3 million ton per month, and the storage size of the inventory of the raw materials and products ranges from a minimum of 80â¯000 to a maximum of 0.3 million tons per tank. div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div: This study aimed to develop a new comprehensive decision framework using an optimization technique for the strategic planning and operation of a petrochemical plant. In achieving the goal, this study integrated three different decision models (the adaptive operation, paper-trading, and price prediction models) to maximize the operating profit of the petrochemical plant under variable market conditions. Specifically, the price prediction model using the SD technique forecasts the prices of the major products and of naphtha as the raw material in the petrochemical plant, and the paper-trading model supports the financial management by determining the best timing and quantities for naphtha purchase. The last embedded model, the adaptive operation model, identifies the optimal production strategy of the naphtha-cracking process by considering the storage levels and market prices. As a result, the seven different case studies revealed that the proposed decision model can generate a huge improvement in profitability (13.8%) against the base case where no model was applied.

Although this study provides a useful and efficient decision model for petrochemical plant planning, the proposed framework still has limits as a complete business intelligence, which enables real petrochemical industries to make strategic decisions, improving operational efficiency and business profitability. Accordingly, future research needs to be undertaken to address the following issues: diversification of the petrochemical value chain by including different raw material options and product markets; integration of system-level solutions (e.g., optimal yield of the naphtha-cracking process) with process operation policy (e.g., optimal temperature and feed rate of the naphtha-cracking reactor).

The main objective of this work is to develop an optimization model for the supply chain of a petrochem. company operating under uncertain operating and economic conditions. First, a deterministic model is developed and tested, and then uncertainties in key parameters are introduced. The optimization model is tested on a typical petrochem. company, manufg. different grades of polyethylene, operating at a single site and using two reactors. The main conclusion of this study is that uncertainties have a dramatic effect on the planning decisions of the petrochem. supply chain. Market demand was found to be the most important parameter, exhibiting a strong impact on the prodn. decisions, followed by the prodn. yields. More enterprises now consider the entire supply chain structure while taking business decisions. They try to identify and manage all crit. relationships both upstream and downstream in their supply chains. Some impediments to this are that the necessary information usually resides across a multitude of resources, is ever changing, and is present in multiple formats. Most supply chain decision support systems (DSSs) are specific to an enterprise and its supply chain, and cannot be easily modified to assist other similar enterprises and industries. In this two-part paper, we propose a unified framework for modeling, monitoring and management of supply chains. The blending component crudes are subject to inventory constraints, which in turn are dynamically affected by the refinery purchase plan including the crude-oil types, amts., and delivery over a planned period of time. The process systems engineering (PSE) as well as the operations research and management science (ORMS) literature has hitherto focused on disparate processes and functions within the enterprise. These themes have included upstream research and development pipeline management, planning and scheduling in batch and continuous manufg. systems and more recently supply chain optimization under uncertainty. In reality, the modern process enterprise functions as a cohesive entity involving several degrees of cross-functional co-ordination across enterprise planning and process functions. The complex organizational structures underlying horizontally and vertically integrated process enterprises challenge our understanding of cross-functional co-ordination and its business impact. This article looks at the impact of enterprise-wide cross-functional coordination on enterprise performance, sustainability and growth prospects. Cross-functional coordination is defined as the integration of strategic and tactical decision-making processes involving the control of financial and inventory flows (both internal and external) as well as resource deployments. Initially, we demonstrate the existence of cross-functional decision-making dependencies using an enterprise network model. Subsequently, we discuss interactions between enterprise planning decisions involving project financing, debt-equity balancing, R&D portfolio selection, risk hedging with real deriv. instruments, supply chain asset creation and marketing contracts which influence decision-making at the activity/process level. Several case studies are included to reinforce the point that planning and process decisions need to be integrated.

In the face of highly competitive markets and const. pressure to reduce lead times, enterprises today consider supply chain management to be the key area where improvements can significantly impact the bottom line. More enterprises now consider the entire supply chain structure while taking business decisions. They try to identify and manage all crit. relationships both upstream and downstream in their supply chains. Some impediments to this are that the necessary information usually resides across a multitude of resources, is ever changing, and is present in multiple formats. Most supply chain decision support systems (DSSs) are specific to an enterprise and its supply chain, and cannot be easily modified to assist other similar enterprises and industries. In this two-part paper, we propose a unified framework for modeling, monitoring and management of supply chains. The first part of the paper describes the framework while the second part illustrates its application to a refinery supply chain. The framework integrates the various elements of the supply chain such as enterprises, their prodn. processes, the assocd. business data and knowledge and represents them in a unified, intelligent and object-oriented fashion. Supply chain elements are classified as entities, flows and relationships. Software agents are used to emulate the entities i.e. various enterprises and their internal departments. Flows-material and information-are modeled as objects. The framework helps to analyze the business policies with respect to different situations arising in the supply chain. We illustrate the framework by two case studies. A DSS for petrochem. cluster management is described together with a prototype DSS for crude procurement in a refinery.

A review. The process systems engineering (PSE) as well as the operations research and management science (ORMS) literature has hitherto focused on disparate processes and functions within the enterprise. These themes have included upstream research and development pipeline management, planning and scheduling in batch and continuous manufg. systems and more recently supply chain optimization under uncertainty. In reality, the modern process enterprise functions as a cohesive entity involving several degrees of cross-functional co-ordination across enterprise planning and process functions. The complex organizational structures underlying horizontally and vertically integrated process enterprises challenge our understanding of cross-functional co-ordination and its business impact. This article looks at the impact of enterprise-wide cross-functional coordination on enterprise performance, sustainability and growth prospects. Cross-functional coordination is defined as the integration of strategic and tactical decision-making processes involving the control of financial and inventory flows (both internal and external) as well as resource deployments. Initially, we demonstrate the existence of cross-functional decision-making dependencies using an enterprise network model. Subsequently, we discuss interactions between enterprise planning decisions involving project financing, debt-equity balancing, R&D portfolio selection, risk hedging with real deriv. instruments, supply chain asset creation and marketing contracts which influence decision-making at the activity/process level. Several case studies are included to reinforce the point that planning and process decisions need to be integrated.
